subject: Cybersecurity
title: DNS Poisoning: Corrupting the Internet's Address Book
description: A quick win: understand DNS Poisoning: Corrupting the Internet's Address Book.

hook.text: What if someone rewrote the phone book so that your bank's number connected to a criminal instead?

buildup.text: DNS cache poisoning inserts false DNS records into a resolver's cache. Users requesting a domain get the wrong IP.

discovery.text: The Kaminsky attack in 2008 showed that DNS poisoning could affect entire ISPs â€” redirecting millions of users.

twist.text: Dan Kaminsky secretly coordinated with every major DNS vendor to patch the flaw before going public. A rare industry-wide fix.

climax.text: DNSSEC adds digital signatures to DNS records, preventing poisoning â€” but adoption remains under 30% of domains.

punchline.text: One researcher found a flaw that could redirect the entire internet.

quiz.question: What does DNSSEC do to prevent DNS poisoning?
options: It adds digital signatures to DNS records to verify authenticity
